properties.description: St. John's NL, April 13-15, 1984. 200,000 people of the Avalon Peninsula were left without heating and lighting for days after overhead electrical wires snapped from the weight of the formation of 15 cm of ice. Power on Bell Island was disrupted for a week. Many small businesses, broadcasting and utility companies felt the effects of the sleet storm; fishing boats sunk.  Homeowners also experienced flooded basements and loss of food stuffs. Areas which received major damage: Fogo Island,  Bell Island, Carbonear Upper Island Cove, Kenmount Hill, St. John's, Bay Roberts, Mt. Pearl, Torbay, Harbour Main, Western Avalon, Sunnyside and Oxen Pond.

properties.name: Winter Storm : South, Central and Western Manitoba
properties.description: South, Central, and Western MB, April 27-28, 1984. Snow, freezing rain and strong wind gusts caused damage to roads, hydro poles and drainage facilities. Municipalities affected were: Grey, Dufferin, Pembina, Portage la Prairie, Stanley and Thompson. Towns affected were: Carman, Morden, Neepawa and Winkler.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Drumheller AB
properties.description: Drumheller AB, 1980.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Prairie provinces
properties.description: Prairie provinces, March 6, 1983. Especially southern Manitoba; the storm forced Winnipeg International Airport to close for two days and toppled several large television towers.  The freezing rain also caused other extensive damage.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Southwestern Quebec
properties.description: Southwestern Quebec, February 19, 1972. A snowstorm produced 80 km/h winds and 37 cm of snow, causing widespread damage.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Barrie ON
properties.description: Barrie ON, March 18, 1973. A bus-truck collision on Hwy 400 caused 12 deaths and 43 blizzard-related injuries.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Montreal QC
properties.description: Montreal QC, March 4, 1971. The city\'s worst snowstorm dumped 47 cm of snow; winds of 110 km/h produced huge drifts; electricity was cut for 2-7 days.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Southwestern Ontario
properties.description: Southwestern Ontario, January 26, 1978. 32 cm of snow in 36 hours.  Heavy snow and high winds (>115 km/hr), extensive damage done; 400 injuries.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Region of Quebec City and Trois-Rivières QC
properties.description: Region of Québec and Trois-Rivières QC, January 2, 1976. A snowstorm caused major blackouts; 10 people were injured; 1 person died, and over 1,100 people provided assistance during the storm.

properties.name: Winter Storm : Niagara Peninsula ON
properties.description: Niagara Peninsula ON, January 28, 1977. The storm lasted 3 days and left 2000 people stranded by the end of the first day. 3,000 vehicles were left abandoned and had to be dug out and towed away.  All cities experienced freezing of individual lines.  St. Catharines reported 300 service calls during that weekend.  Ontario Hydro had two major breaks in electrical power.

properties.name: Tornado : Saint Bonaventure QC
properties.description: Saint Bonaventure Region of Trois-Rivières QC, July 25, 1975. A tornado, which started around 5:40 pm, caused electrical failures and much damage; 75 dwellings were hit, leaving 45 uninhabitable; 918 people had to be relocated. There were 59 people injured, and 3 people died. The church was completely destroyed.

properties.name: Tornado : Maniwaki, Déléage, Egan, South Region of Outaouais QC
properties.description: Maniwaki, Déléage and Egan-South Region of Outaouais QC, May 14, 1971. A tornado damaged 71 residences, and completely destroyed 6. 25 families were evacuated (based on family of 4), 11 people were injured and 2 people were killed.

properties.name: Tornado : Sudbury, Lively, Coppercliff and Field ON
properties.description: Sudbury, Lively, Coppercliff and Field ON, August 20, 1970.  An F3 tornado (wind speeds of 252-330 km/h) caused the loss of six lives, 200 injuries, and extensive damage to property.

properties.name: Tornado : Windsor ON
properties.description: Windsor ON, April 3, 1974. 9 dead, 30 injured.

properties.name: Tornado : Montreal (Sainte-Rose) QC
properties.description: Montreal (Sainte-Rose) QC, June 14, 1982. 5 fatalities, 26 injured, and extensive damage; hundreds of homes and barns flattened.

properties.name: Tornado : Reeces Corners ON
properties.description: Reeces Corners ON, May 3, 1983.

properties.name: Tornado : Grande Prairie and Drayton Valley AB
properties.description: Grande Prairie and Drayton Valley AB, 1984.

properties.name: Tornado : Eastern Ontario and Western Quebec
properties.description: Eastern Ontario and Western Quebec, July 15, 1984. 1 dead, 43 injured; destruction of 300 houses. Québec: Sheenboro, Blue Sea Lake, Bouchette, Caymant Region of Outaouais. In Québec, 37 houses were damaged, 10 houses destroyed.

properties.name: Tornado : London ON
properties.description: London ON, September 2,1984. 30 injured.

properties.name: Tornado : Woodstock ON
properties.description: Woodstock ON, August 7, 1979.

properties.name: Tornado : Goderich ON
properties.description: Goderich ON, August 21-22, 2011. At approximately 16:00 EDT, a Fujita Scale Three (F3: winds near 250 km/hr) tornado touched down in the town of Goderich, ON causing extensive damages including damaged roof tops, fallen trees, gas leaks and hydroelectricity outages. Natural gas was off to 90% for the town of Goderich as well as to residents in the surrounding municipalities. As of 10:30 EDT on August 22, 2011, power had been restored to most of the afffected area.

properties.name: Tornado : Hopeville to Barrie ON
properties.description: Hopeville to Barrie ON, May 31, 1985; 12 dead, hundreds injured; 800 homeless. More than 100 buildings were damaged, 300 houses were also destroyed. Severe thunderstorms and hail. Power outages, damage to 150 farms.

properties.name: Tornado : Kawacatoose First Nation SK
properties.description: Kawacatoose First Nation SK, July 2, 2010.  An F3 tornado ripped through the Kawacatoose First Nation, destroying 15 homes and causing $2.3 million in damages.

properties.name: Tornado : Déléage to Mont-Laurier
properties.description: Déléage to Mont-Laurier, August 4, 2009. The season's most powerful tornado occurred along a track from Déléage, through Aumond, to Mont-Laurier in the upper Laurentians. It blew away roofs, pushed over walls, tossed cars around, snapped utility poles and downed power lines leaving 4,000 without power. Among the 40 damaged homes in Mont-Laurier, 28 were rendered uninhabitable. There were no serious injuries. The tornado caused about $6 million in insured losses. The tornado's path through Mont-Laurier was 300 m wide, but its 40-km track was an unusually long distance for a tornado in Quebec and a strong indication of the storm's severity. The last time a stronger tornado touched down in the province was on the same day in 1994 when an F3 tornado destroyed more than 400 homes in Aylmer.

properties.name: Tornado : Toronto, Windsor, Vaughan and Newmarket ON
properties.description: Toronto, Windsor, Vaughan and Newmarket ON, August 20, 2009.  A supercell storm developed just south of Lake Huron and tracked northeastward for a remarkable 200 km. The heat and humidity hanging over Ontario increased once the clouds disappeared.  At the same time, a squall line developed over Lower Michigan and traveled across Ontario. This system produced straight-line winds from Windsor to northeast of Toronto and destructive tornados in Vaughan and Newmarket. While these tornados were wreaking havoc just north of Toronto, another series of supercell thunderstorms was spawning tornados in portions of Simcoe County, Muskoka and Parry Sound Districts to the east of Georgian Bay, and north towards Lake Nipissing. In total, the day's weather produced 19 confirmed tornadoes, including: four F0, eleven F1, and four F2. That was the greatest number of F2 tornadoes in Ontario in one day since the Barrie/Central Ontario tornadoes of May 31, 1985. It was also a new Canadian record for the most confirmed tornadoes in one day. Violent winds snapped trees, lifted roofs, flattened cars, mowed down fences, collapsed farm buildings, and inflicted property losses around $100 million. The first tornado of the day touched down in the town of Durham in Grey County, killing an 11-year-old boy as he left a nearby conservation area day camp.  About 600 homes, mostly in the communities of Maple and Woodbridge, were damaged. Thirty-eight were demolished and declared unsafe. Major flooding occurred along the lakeshore, and at the peak of the storm Hydro One reported that 69,000 customers had lost power.

properties.name: Tornado : Midland ON
properties.description: Midland ON, June 23, 2010.  An F2 tornado destroyed approximately 50 homes and caused damages estimated to be $15 million.  The F2 classification means that wind speeds between 180 and 240 kilometres per hour were reached.  12 people were reported to be injured.  Ontario provided immediate provincial assistance of up to $1 million to aid in cleanup and repairs.

properties.name: Tornado : Leamington ON
properties.description: Leamington ON, June 6, 2010. A strong thunderstorm cell moved over the southern portions of Essex County. It spawned 4 tornadoes and a series of damaging wind gusts along an intermittent path of damage about 40 kilometres in length. The most significant damage was done by an F2 tornado which swept through the south end of the town of Leamington, with peak winds between 180 and 240 km/h.  Approximately 4,500 hydro customers were left without power, and 12 homes were deemed unsafe due to damages.  The Red Cross provided an emergency shelter to help in the wake of the disaster.

properties.name: Tornado : Portage la Prairie MB
properties.description: Portage la Prairie MB, June 22, 1922. A tornado resulted in five dead, many injured.

properties.name: Tornado : Elie MB
properties.description: Elie MB, June 22, 2007. Tornadoes touched down west of Winnipeg in Eli and near Oakville, ripping apart several homes and flipping over a semi-trailer on the Trans-Canada Highway. Miraculously, no one appears to have been seriously hurt.

properties.name: Tornado : Lanaudière QC
properties.description: Lanaudière QC, June 29, 2008. A tornado, with winds at times reaching 120km/h and producing hail the size of golf balls, caused a great deal of property damage. Nearly 15,000 homes were left without power.

properties.name: Tornado : Winnipeg MB
properties.description: Winnipeg MB, July 11, 2008. Wind caused havoc across Winnipeg and eastern Manitoba, including one area that may have been hit by a tornado. Up to 5,000 homes lost power in total.

properties.name: Tornado : Windsor to Tecumseh ON
properties.description: Windsor to Tecumseh ON, June 17, 1946; 17 dead, hundreds injured; 400 homes damaged; 150 barns and farm buildings destroyed.

properties.name: Tornado : Regina SK
properties.description: Regina SK, November 1950.

properties.name: Tornado : Sarnia ON
properties.description: Sarnia ON, May 21, 1953. 7 dead, 40 injured and 500 left homeless.

properties.name: Tornado : White Point Beach NS
properties.description: White Point Beach NS, January 30, 1954. A tornado producing hail and lightning hit the coast of Nova Scotia near Liverpool.

properties.name: Tornado : Amaranth MB
properties.description: Amaranth MB, May 1958.

properties.name: Tornado : Huron and Perth counties ON
properties.description: Huron/Perth counties ON, April 17, 1967.

properties.name: Tornado : Grande Prairie AB
properties.description: Grande Prairie AB, July 8, 2004.  A tornado swept through Grand Prairie, snapping hydro poles and tearing shingles from buildings.

properties.name: Tornado : Pine Lake AB
properties.description: Pine Lake AB, July 14, 2000.  A tornado hit Pine Lake at 300 kilometres an hour, killing 12 people and injuring more than 140.  Close to one-thousand people were displaced from a campsite as their recreational vehicles were damaged.

properties.name: Tornado : Drummondville QC
properties.description: Drummondville QC, July 6, 1999. A tornado went through the city of Drummondville ripping roofs from 20 houses and injuring a number of people. One child was killed as a tree collapsed on his tent while he was camping.  In total, 60 homes were damaged and 200 people were forced to flee from their homes. The tornado first hit Berthierville then skipped across the river and headed southeast to Drummondville. At least 4000 people were without power for 2 days.

properties.name: Tornado : Grey County, Wellington and Dufferin County ON
properties.description: Grey, Wellington, and Dufferin counties ON, April 20, 1996. Two F3 class tornadoes touched down in Grey County (Holland Centre), Wellington and Dufferin County. Significant property damage occurred; 9 people were injured by the 2 tornadoes. -80.54  44.122

properties.name: Tornado : Saskatchewan
properties.description: Saskatchewan, June 21, 1999. Stormy weather spawned heavy rain and a tornado.  The storm caused extensive damage to roofs and structures due to high winds in Moose Jaw, Regina and Saskatoon.  A number of fires were sparked from lightning, including one which hit a long-term care home in Alingly, 30 km northwest of Prince Albert.

properties.name: Tornado : Aylmer QC
properties.description: Aylmer QC, August 4, 1994. A F3 tornado hits the heavily populated district of Aylmer. 385 houses sustained damages, 12 being totally destroyed and 40 being heavily damaged. 250 families had to be evacuated (based on family of 4), and 4 people were injured.

properties.name: Tornado : Southern Ontario
properties.description: Southern Ontario, August 29, 1990. Tornadoes, high winds and thunderstorms caused crop damage and the destruction of several buildings in the communities of Lobo, Komoka, Frome, Port Stanley, Southwold and Kendall; 6 minor injuries were reported.

properties.name: Tornado : Sarnia ON
properties.description: Sarnia ON, March 27, 1991.

properties.name: Tornado : Maskinongé QC
properties.description: St. Lawrence River QC, August 27, 1991. The tornado affected the Village of Maskinongé; the tornado crossed the St. Lawrence River and touched down in Notre-Dame de Pierreville where a few summer cottages were destroyed and some minor injuries occurred; it also touched down in Saint Wenceslas where minor damage was reported; there were no deaths, 15 people injured, only one seriously; 60% of all buildings in the village of Maskinongé were damaged, the power lines were down and telephone service stopped; no drinking water was available.

properties.name: Tornado : Winnipeg MB
properties.description: Winnipeg MB, July 6, 1987. A thunderstorm caused at least 2 tornadoes in Winnipeg; strong winds and 40 mm of rain in two and a half hours caused flash flooding and resulted in considerable property damage.

properties.name: Tornado : Edmonton AB
properties.description: Edmonton AB, July 31, 1987. 27 dead, 600 injured, 1700 homeless; widespread heavy rainfall from a powerful tornado hit Edmonton on July 31,1987; 300 mm of rain fell in 3 days; the Smoky, Wapiti, Simonette, and Kakwa Rivers rose up to 7-8 metres in some areas; the tornado touched down in Edmonton and moved northeast; hailstorms were reported during the tornado; much of the damage was caused by hailstorms accompanying the tornado.

properties.name: Tornado : Montmartre SK
properties.description: Montmartre SK, July 1989. The Canadian Red Cross assisted the victims.

properties.name: Tornado : Southeastern Saskatchewan
properties.description: Southeastern Saskatchewan, July 22, 1920. The tornado swept over a large portion of southeastern Saskatchewan, devastating the area. Four people died, more than a dozen were injured, and losses to property, equipment, crops and live stock were estimated to be in excess of $100,000 (1920 dollars). Many settlers lost both their homes and livelihoods in one sudden unexpected blow. Large scale relief was undertaken by the Canadian Red Cross to assist 42 affected families in Alameda, Frobisher, Lampman, Steelman, and Estevan SK.

properties.name: Tornado : Regina SK
properties.description: Regina SK, June 30 1912. 28 dead, hundreds injured, 2500 homeless; more than 400 of the finest buildings in the city were destroyed.

properties.name: Tsunami : Port Alberni BC
properties.description: Port Alberni BC, March 28, 1964. An earthquake in Alaska of magnitude 8.5 generated a 3.6 m tsunami; no Canadian fatalities.

properties.name: Tsunami : British Columbia
properties.description: British Columbia, 1960. Outer coast; an earthquake of magnitude 9.5 in Chile caused a 1.2 metre wave at the Tofino tide gauge; run-up was higher in many areas; damage to log booms occurred along the west coast of Vancouver Island and the Queen Charlotte Islands.

properties.name: Tsunami : Burin Peninsula NL
properties.description: Burin Peninsula NF, November 18, 1929. An offshore earthquake (magnitude 7.2) on the floor of the Atlantic Ocean caused a massive submarine slump (landslide), which generated a large ocean wave (tsunami); the tsunami drowned 27 people when it struck the Burin Peninsula. A tsunami was also reported to have struck Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, drowning one individual.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northern Saskatchewan
properties.description: Northern Saskatchewan, July 1936. During the week before July 20, 194 sq. km of Saskatchewan timberland burned.

properties.name: Wildfire : Rainy River and Dance Township ON
properties.description: Dance Township ON, October 10-15, 1938; 17 dead, 155 homeless, 37,230 ha of forest were destroyed.  The fire was caused by the settlers by brush fires.  The fire got out of control due to the lack of water in the area at the time.

properties.name: Wildfire : Quebec and Ontario
properties.description: Ontario and Québec, July-August 1955. More than 100 forest fires burned longer than four weeks; on August 4 there were 150 fires.

properties.name: Wildfire : Mississagi ON
properties.description: Mississagi/Chapleau (a First Nation reserve) ON, May to late October 1948. 261,017 ha destroyed.

properties.name: Wildfire : Gogama ON
properties.description: Gogama ON, May 14 - June 15, 1941. No dead, 133,827 ha destroyed.

properties.name: Wildfire : Deschambault Lake SK
properties.description: Deschambault Lake SK, July 1, 2008. Smoke from forest fires forced Deschambault Lake residents from their homes.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northern Saskatchewan
properties.description: Northern Saskatchewan, June 30, 2008. Some 2,000 people from the communities of Sandy Bay, Stony Rapids, Pelican Narrows, Black Lake and Uranium City in Saskatchewan's far north have been forced out of their homes due to 64 forest fires.

properties.name: Wildfire : Halifax NS
properties.description: Halifax NS, June 13, 2008. An unforeseen brush fire ravaged a wooded area east of Halifax. The fire destroyed two homes and forced 5,000 residents to evacuate their homes.

properties.name: Wildfire : Newbrook AB
properties.description: Newbrook AB, May 16, 2008. A forest fire that was raging north of Edmonton destroyed two homes and forced more than 150 people from their homes.

properties.name: Wildfire : Pukatawagan MB
properties.description: Pukatawagan MB, June 10, 2008. A town in northern Manitoba has declared a state of emergency as food and other necessities dwindle because of a burned-out railway bridge. More than 2,600 people in Pukatawagan, located about 900kms northwest of Winnipeg, are facing shortages of food and baby products.

properties.name: Wildfire : Norway House and Sherridon MB
properties.description: Norway House and Sherridon MB, May 28, 2008. A forest fire, that stretches from a point to the south of Lynn Lake in the northwest corner of the province south to Norway House Cree Nation and east to the Island Lake First Nations, has forced as many as 3,330 people out of their homes.

properties.name: Wildfire : South Indian Lake MB
properties.description: South Indian Lake MB, July 20, 2007. A forest fire just 16kms south of the South Indian Lake reserve had grown to more than 60,000 hectares in size, blanketing the community of 1,100 people in heavy smoke.

properties.name: Wildfire : Kootenay BC
properties.description: Kootenay BC, August 1, 2007. Forest fires raging in southeastern BC triggered a state of local emergency and caused three homes to be evacuated and power to be cut to more than 3,000 homes.

properties.name: Wildfire : Natuashish NL
properties.description: Natuashish NL, August 3, 2007. A forest fire was accidentally caused by a group of swimmers. The fire destroyed over 200 hectares of forest and forced the evacuation of 600 residents.

properties.name: Wildfire : Sept-Îles QC
properties.description: Sept-Îles QC, May 27, 2007. A major forest fire is raging over 11,000 hectares in the Abitibi region, about 530kms northwest of Montreal, forcing the removal of 1,500 residents.

properties.name: Wildfire : Happy Valley - Goose Bay NL
properties.description: Happy Valley - Goose Bay NL, June 17, 2007.  A forest fire in Happy Valley - Goose Bay forced the evacuation of 200 homes.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northwest Ontario
properties.description: Northwest Ontario, May 13, 2007. Up to 300 people have been forced from their cottages in an area about 75kms west of Thunder Bay, where the biggest fire - Thunder Bay 37 - had raged through about 11,500 hectares.

properties.name: Wildfire : Tumbler Ridge BC
properties.description: Tumbler Ridge BC, July 3, 2006. Four thousand residents were ordered to vacate their homes as a forest fire came close enough to threaten the coal mining town.

properties.name: Wildfire : Nordegg AB
properties.description: Nordegg AB, July 4, 2006. About 130 residents, and dozens of campers, were forced to leave Nordegg after a forest fire came within 2kms of the village.

properties.name: Wildfire : Cariboo-Chilcotin BC
properties.description: Cariboo-Chilcotin BC, July 6, 2006. About 600 people living in remote communities in BC's Cariboo-Chilcotin region have been forced from their homes by the threat of two massive wildfires.

properties.name: Wildfire : Mistissini QC
properties.description: Mistissini QC, June 16, 2006. Residents of a Cree reserve were evacuated from their homes for the second time in as many weeks as a forest fire once again threatened their community.

properties.name: Wildfire : Cross Lake, Seymourville MB
properties.description: Manitoba, April-May 1999. There were 65 fires burning in the province.  The 1200 residents of Cross Lake were forced to flee their homes on April 29, when a Forest fire came within 300 metres of the town. The majority of residents were evacuated to the nearby towns of Thompson and Norway House.  On May 3, 600 residents of three small communities clustered on the east shore of Lake Winnipeg (Seymourville, Hollow Water First Nation and Manigotagan), were evacuated to the nearby town of Bissett to avoid the oncoming Forest fire which came within four kilometres of the communities. The fire covered 52 sq. km. and it took about 500 firefighters, 30 helicopters and five water bombers to battle the blaze.

properties.name: Wildfire : Haileybury ON
properties.description: Haileybury and northern region ON, September 30 - October 5 1922. 43 dead (unofficially as high as 150), 11,000 homeless, 5180 square kilometres burned.

properties.name: Wildfire : Chapleau ON
properties.description: Chapleau ON, May 27, 2010. A forest fire, which started in the Chapleau area near Wawa, burned through approximately 22 hydro poles and caused a power outage affecting approximately 2,000 local residents.

properties.name: Wildfire : Williams Lake, Chilcotin, Houston, Burns Lake and Fraser Lake BC
properties.description: Williams Lake, Chilcotin, Houston, Burns Lake and Fraser Lake BC, July to September 2010.  Due to little precipitation and lightning strikes, from July 28 to July 31, the number of fires in British Columbia went from 600 to 1,100.  On August 18, a significant wind blew through the interior causing substantial growth of the fires.  All evacuation orders and alerts were removed by the first week of September.  Approximately 330,000 hectares burned due to 1,673 fires.  Over 1,400 personnel from out-of-province assisted with fighting the fires.  Two airtanker pilots died when their plane crashed.  Both the city of Vancouver and the Government of Alberta issued air quality warnings due to smoke caused by the fires.

properties.name: Wildfire : County of Thorhild AB
properties.description: County of Thorhild AB, May 12, 2010. A wildfire in the county of Thorhild, north of Edmonton, affected thousands of acres of land.  The community of Opal experienced numerous evacuation orders, up to 100 homes on May 17. The Province of Alberta provided $10 million in funding under the Municipal Wildfire Assistance Program to aid in the community's recovery.

properties.name: Wildfire : Wemotaci reserve and La Tuque QC
properties.description: Wemotaci reserve and La Tuque QC, May 23, 2010.   A 39 hectare fire forced the evacuation of 1,300 residents from the Wemotaci reserve.  This was just one of over 50 fires throughout the province that raged for weeks, resulting in large amounts of smoke leading to a smog alert for Montreal, Vaudreuil, Soulanges, Huntingdon, Richelieu Valley, St. Hyacinthe, Lachute, St. Jerome, Lanaudiere, Mauricie, Drummondville, and Bois-Franc.

properties.name: Wildfire : Kelowna, Kamloops and Cariboo BC
properties.description: Kelowna, Kamloops and Cariboo BC, July 18, 2009.  Fire season 2009 had 3,049 fires, 213 of which were wildland-urban interface fires. On July 18, fires broke out in the Glenrosa and Rose Valley communities of West Kelowna, combined with the Terrace Mountain fire west of Fintry, which led to multiple evacuation orders and alerts. July also saw an abundance of lightning storms leading to other fires of note throughout the province. Temperatures continued to break record highs and little precipitation was received in most areas. As September began, all personnel continued to work hard to contain fires across the Kamloops and Cariboo regions. The Lava Canyon fire, the largest, was nearly 55,000 hectares and growing.  There were over 100 notable fires during this fire season: at least 27 caused evacuation orders and at least a dozen more caused evacuation alerts.  Approximately 20,000 people were evacuated. One helicopter pilot lost his life in the line of duty.

properties.name: Wildfire : 13km East of Cranberry Portage MB
properties.description: 13km East of Cranberry Portage MB, June 15, 2010. A fire approximately 13 km east of Cranberry Portage grew to approximately 55,000 hectares in size.  Residents from Cranberry Portage were advised to evacuate and the road to Sherridon was temporary closed to all but local traffic.

properties.name: Wildfire : Cochrane and Matheson ON
properties.description: Cochrane and Matheson ON, July 29, 1916. Both were destroyed;  233 deaths (unofficially as high as 400), 8000 made homeless; the fire resulted from a small blaze started by lightening and augmented by fires started by sparks from a passing locomotive.

properties.name: Wildfire : Cochrane ON
properties.description: Cochrane and northern region ON, July 11, 1911. A Forest fire resulted in 73 deaths (unofficially in the hundreds), 200 made homeless, 804,650 sq km destroyed.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northern Manitoba
properties.description: Northern MB, May-September 1989. One of the worst forest fires in Canadian history raged across northern Manitoba forcing the evacuation of roughly 25,000 people in approximately 25 communities; many were airlifted to Winnipeg. In 1989, Manitoba experienced 1,229 forest fires.

properties.name: Wildfire : Radisson QC
properties.description: Radisson QC, July 22, 1989. Forest fires caused the evacuation of 300 people from Radisson to Montréal and Val d'Or.

properties.name: Wildfire : Whitedog Lake ON
properties.description: Whitedog Lake ON, 1988. 500 evacuated.

properties.name: Wildfire : Grand Falls NL
properties.description: Grand Falls NL, May 15-16, 1986. 1000 evacuated at Grand Falls; among the worst of a series of more than 100 Forest fires burning across Eastern Canada as a result of unseasonably warm, dry weather.

properties.name: Wildfire : Upper Gagetown and Burton NB
properties.description: Upper Gagetown and Burton NB, May 15-16, 1986. 1000 evacuated between Upper Gagetown and Burton; among the worst of a series of more than 100 forest fires burning across Eastern Canada as a result of unseasonably warm, dry weather.

properties.name: Wildfire : Waswanipi reserve QC
properties.description: Waswanipi Reserve QC, June 2, 1986. A major forest fire forced the evacuation of 500 people living on the Waswanipi reserve.

properties.name: Wildfire : Betsiamites, Ragueneau et Baie-Comeau QC
properties.description: Betsiamites, Ragueneau and Baie Comeau QC, June 29, 1991. Residents of the Montagnais Reserve of Betsiamites and the community of Ragueneau were evacuated; nine fires were reported in the area of Baie Comeau; fire fighting activity concentrated on the two largest fires; the larger fire covered 1900 square km at Betsiamites, about 50 kilometres west of Baie Comeau; the second fire covered 900 square km at Forestville, approximately 90 kilometres west of Baie Comeau; overall there were 7000 evacuees (Red Cross Statistics).

properties.name: Wildfire : Old Crow YT
properties.description: Old Crow YT, July 20, 1990. Fires threatened the community of Old Crow, north of Inuvik, requiring the evacuation of the community residents.

properties.name: Wildfire : British Columbia
properties.description: British Columbia, July 24, 1994.  A Forest fire that destroyed 5.9 ha of land caused the evacuation of 3000 people.

properties.name: Wildfire : Badger NL
properties.description: Badger NL, June 28 - July 1, 1999. A 6,500 ha Forest fire forced almost 1,000 people in Badger to leave their homes when the fire came within 250 m of the town.  Residents returned home on July 1.

properties.name: Wildfire : La Ronge SK
properties.description: La Ronge SK, April-May 1999. Firefighters battled a Forest fire that caused the evacuation of the town of La Ronge, and destroyed 8 buildings.  The fire lasted for about a week.  The fire stretched for 8 km2, and it took 248 firefighters supported by water bombers to extinguish it.

properties.name: Wildfire : Beardmore ON
properties.description: Beardmore ON, May 1999.  There were 60 fires burning in the province.  A 50,540 ha fire forced 300 residents from Beardmore to move to Geraldton on May 4.  Another 17,000 ha fire forced the evacuation of the Bearskin Lake First Nation (375 residents) and Pic Mobert First Nation (400 residents) on May 6.  The fires forced the closure of sections of Highways 11 and 17.  The evacuees were allowed to return home on May 8.  The Canadian Forces provided humanitarian assistance in Geraldton and Bearskin Lake.

properties.name: Wildfire : Burwash Landing YT
properties.description: Burwash Landing YT, June 12-22, 1999. A Forest fire caused the evacuation of 69 residents and tourists from the community of Burwash Landing.  The fire reached the town on June 13, destroyed 6 houses and caused extensive damage to other buildings. Residents were allowed back to the town on June 19. Over 100 firefighters fought the blaze. The Alaska highway, a major tourist route, was shut down between Beaver Creek and Haines Junction.  The fire burned 3200 hectares of land and was put out on June 22.

properties.name: Wildfire : East of Lake Winnipeg MB
properties.description: East of Lake Winnipeg MB, March 5, 1999. Forests in Ontario and Manitoba were consumed by this event.

properties.name: Wildfire : Swan Hills AB
properties.description: Swan Hills AB, May 1998. Approximately 155000 ha was burned by 35 fires.  The most dangerous fires were located in the area of Slave Lake and Swan Hills. A fire 15 km away caused the Town of Swan Hills to activate its municipal emergency plan on May 5 and evacuate 2,400 residents.  Military assistance was required, and several highways were closed. On May 14, Swan Hills was evacuated for a second time. A thunderstorm on May 15, accompanied by a period cold/damp weather suppressed many of the fires in Alberta. Military assistance ended on May 21.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northern Ontario
properties.description: Northern Ontario, July 1998. During the month of July, there were over 130 fires in Northern Ontario. Approximately 1,425 people were evacuated from various communities, and over 3,700 hectares of forest was burnt. Main fires occurred near the following regions: Bearskin Lake, Terrace Bay, Kasabonika Lake, Summer Beaver, Webique, Muskrat Lake, Thunder Bay and Lansdowne.

properties.name: Wildfire : Tibbet Lake NT
properties.description: Tibbet Lake, NT, July 22-31, 1998. A State of Emergency was declared when a 60000 ha fire was burning in the area of Tibbet Lake. The area north of Powder Point on Ingraham Trail was evacuated and Ingraham Trail was closed to all traffic. The fire destroyed three vacation cabins and edged within 5 km of cabins and lodges around Consolation Lake, 70 km northeast of Yellowknife. On July 31, the fire reached 140000 ha in size.

properties.name: Wildfire : British Columbia
properties.description: British Columbia, August 1998. During this month, there were 687 Forest fires burning in British Columbia. Approximately 10,600 people were evacuated, 42,115 hectares of forest burnt, 36 properties were damaged, and livestock losses were reported. Major fires occurred in the following areas: Salmon Arm-Fly Hills  Fire (see 1998.018); Vernon-Valley of Sun/Fintry/Parker's Cove; Kamloops-Cherry Creek Fire; Kamloops-Greenstone Mountain Fire; McBride-Doare River Fire; Telegraph Creek; Boston Bar-Nahatlatch Lake; Lillooet-Fountain Valley. Barriere-Dunn Lake-Birch Fire, and Avaola-Elevator were smaller, but still significant fires.  Military assistance was requested in many areas.

properties.name: Wildfire : Salmon Arm BC
properties.description: Salmon Arm BC, August 10-17, 1998. A State of Emergency was declared by the Premier on Aug.10 for the Salmon Arm-Fly Hills Fire, it was cancelled on Aug.17. The fire covered 6300 hectares and destroyed 20 houses and 15 farm buildings. An inquiry was called in October 1998 to determine whether the BC Forest Service had problems handling the fire.

properties.name: Wildfire : Sahtu Region of the Northwest Territories
properties.description: Sahtu region of the Northwest Territories, June 6-15, 1995.  A Forest fire was first sited in Fort Norman (in the Hamlet of Tulita), and then spread to Norman Wells, Yellowknife and Deline. The fires were started by lightning strikes. Damage was incurred by provincial, municipal and private property.  Fort Norman was evacuated on June 6, and Norman Wells was evacuated on June 9. Norman Wells was under a State of Emergency from June 814.

properties.name: Wildfire : North Central Saskatchewan
properties.description: North central Saskatchewan, May 29, 1995. Lightning started 56 fires on May 29 and as the season progressed, 2,500 people were evacuated from 16 communities and 18 highways were closed. At the height of the outbreak, 4,000 people were fighting the fires.  While there was no loss of life and minimal loss of structures, 16,000 square kilometres (160,000 hectares) of forest were burned and 48 million cubic meters of wood were lost.

properties.name: Wildfire : Timmins ON
properties.description: Timmins ON, May 29, 1997. The city declared an emergency when a 100 hectare forest fire jumped the Mattagami River, forcing a one day evacuation of approximately 400 residents.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northwest of Matagami QC
properties.description: Northwest of Matagami QC, June 10, 1997. About 125 forest fires burned in Québec, 3 of which were serious and required the evacuation of 300 people from James Bay, 200 from Selby mine (85 km northwest of Matagami), and 1100 from the Weymontachie First Nations Reserve.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northwest Ontario
properties.description: Northwest Ontario, May 13, 2007. Up to 300 people have been forced from their cottages in an area about 75kms west of Thunder Bay, where the biggest fire - Thunder Bay 37 - had raged through about 11,500 hectares.

properties.name: Wildfire : Iroquois Falls, Kirkland Lake, Timmins areas ON
properties.description: Iroquois Falls, Kirkland Lake, Timmins areas ON, June 12, 1997. A fire burning southeast of Timmins burned hydro wires which left the town of Foleyet without power for one day; people were evacuated from approximately 750 homes in the Westin Lake, Watabeag Lake (south of Iroquois Falls), Sesekinika and Kenogami (west of Kirkland Lake) areas; 73 people from the Wahgoshig First Nation were evacuated to Timmins.

properties.name: Wildfire : Peerless Lake, Trout Lake AB
properties.description: Peerless Lake and Trout Lake AB, June 23, 2002.  The Peerless Lake Complex involved three separate fires within a small area approximately 155 km north of Slave Lake. These three fires forced the MD of Opportunity No. 17 to evacuate approximately 600 people to Red Earth.  The wild fires consumed a total of 15,438 ha of forest.

properties.name: Wildfire : Turnor Lake SK
properties.description: Turnor Lake SK, June 25, 2002. Three hundred and fifty residents of Turnor Lake, located 600 km northwest of Saskatoon, were evacuated to nearby towns. The fire was charged by exceptionally dry and hot weather, and winds pushed the fire towards Turnor Lake. Water bombers continuously dropped their payload on the fire, while the town buildings and trees were showered by industrial sprinkler systems.

properties.name: Wildfire : Hawes/Patuanak SK
properties.description: Hawes/Patuanak SK, June 28-30, 2002. One hundred three evacuated.

properties.name: Wildfire : Crutwell, Dillon, Hatchett Lake, Pelican Narrows, Deschambeault, Wahpeton First Nation, Nordell, Peter Pond SK
properties.description: Crutwell, Dillon, Hatchett Lake, Pelican Narrows, Deschambeault, Wahpeton First Nation, Nordell, Peter Pond SK, June 28 - July 1, 2002. Five hundred six evacuated.

properties.name: Wildfire : Nemiscau region, near James Bay QC
properties.description: Nemiscau region, near James Bay QC, July 2, 2002. Of 50 forest fires burning in Quebec around this time, the Nemiscau fire was the most noticeable.  The fire travelled within 800 metres of the native village of Nemaska. A total of 630 Chisasibi and Nemiscau-region residents were evacuated. The fire was ignited by intense thunder and lightning storms and destroyed over 600 km2 of forest. Consequently, 6000 Quebec forestry workers were laid-off. Hydro-Quebec disconnected its service to 500 000 people given the proximity of the fire to a major power line. Smoke could be seen in most of Quebec, parts of Ontario, and the northeastern United States.

properties.name: Wildfire : Near community of Sheshatshui and town of North West River NL
properties.description: Near the community of Sheshatshui and the Town of North West River NL, July 3, 2002.  A forest fire ignited 10-12 km from the community of Sheshatshui and the Town of North West River. Approximately 1200 residents were evacuated to the town of Happy Valley-Goose Bay. The fire burned 3km2 of forest.

properties.name: Wildfire : Kee-Way-Win FN; Townships of Terrace Bay and Schrieber; Village of Rossport; Pays Plat FN; Deer Lake FN, ON
properties.description: Kee-Way-Win FN; Townships of Terrace Bay and Schrieber; Village of Rossport; Pays Plat FN; Deer Lake FN, ON, July 2002. Members of several communities were concerned by nearby fires and smoke. More than 1000 people were evacuated to Thunder Bay, Geraldton and Sioux Lookout. Municipal emergency declarations occurred in six communities.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northern Alberta and Conklin
properties.description: Northern AB and Conklin, May 14 - June 7, 2002. The House River Fire was first spotted on May 17, 2002. It burned 248,243 hectares. The fire was approximately 100 km north of Lac La Biche. At its peak, 1,000 firefighters were on the fireline. The task was difficult given the strong and shifting winds and minimal precipitation. The fire perimeter was secured by June 7, 2002. This was Alberta's second largest forest fire since 1961. On May 27 the Regional Municipality of Wood Buffalo evacuated approximately 1,550 people. There were approximately 1,300 from work camps, and 250 from the community of Conklin. All individuals were allowed to return on June 8, 2002.

properties.name: Wildfire : Montreal Lake SK
properties.description: Montreal Lake SK, May 20-22, 2002.  Extreme burning conditions existed throughout Saskatchewan at this time.  Winds gusting at 50 to 60 km/h aided the spread of fires (around 48 in total), mostly in grasses and brush.  This specific fire was first spotted around the Bittern Lake area and was moving north towards the eastern part of the community of Montreal Lake.  Approximately 130 evacuees from this community and the Montreal Lake Cree Nation were moved to Prince Albert.

properties.name: Wildfire : Manitoba
properties.description: Manitoba, April to October 2003. The province of Manitoba experienced 1,148 wildfires during the 2003 season. While the fires actually began at the end of March,  damages began to affect communities in April. The Thompson area was particularly affected. A lightening strike near Thompson began a forest fire that was sustained through hot and dry weather. Approximately 900 people were evacuated, many from aboriginal comunities including: 250 people from Red Sucker Lake First Nation and 92 people from God's River First Nation were evacuated due to fires that began in July. In August, approximately 155 people were evacuated from Shamattawa while 250 were evacuated from Split Lake.

properties.name: Wildfire : Eastern Passage, Cole Harbour NS
properties.description: Cole Harbour, Eastern Passage NS, May 19, 2003.  A forest fire started in a bog near Cole Harbour.  High winds and dry conditions helped the fire spread out of control burning 240 hectares and forcing the evacuation of 240 homes.  Approximately 500 people were evacuated near Eastern Passage in northeast of Halifax.  No damage or injuries reported.

properties.name: Wildfire : Southeastern British Columbia and Southwestern Alberta
properties.description: Southeastern British Columbia and Southwestern Alberta; July and August 2003.  Dozens of communities were evacuated due to wildfires started by lightning and careless fire use.  Over 50,000 people were evacuated and firefighting costs alone are estimated at $400 million dollars.

properties.name: Wildfire : Norman Wells NT
properties.description: Norman Wells, NT, July 21, 2003. Lightening started a fire in an on old-growth black spruce forest approximately 17 km from Norman Wells. The fire was sustained by high temperatures and gusting winds. Norman Wells declared a state of emergency. About 100 people were evacuated due to thick smoke. Those with respiratory problems, the elderly, and the young were evacuated by plane to Inuvik while others were sent to nearby communities via boat.

properties.name: Wildfire : Chibougamau, James Bay QC
properties.description: Chibougamau, James Bay QC, June 6, 2005.  In Northern Québec a forest fire near Chibougamau forced the evacuation of approximately 200 residents.  Approximately 650 Hydro-Quebec workers were airlifted in an evacuation operation in the James Bay area due to another forest fire. There were 57 active forest fires in Quebec at the time.  Forest fires have destroyed approximately 170,000 hectares of forest in Quebec this year.

properties.name: Wildfire : Chisasibi QC
properties.description: Chisasibi QC, May 29, 2005. Forest fire forced about 600 people in the Cree community of Chisasibi to be evacuated to the nearby village of Radisson.  The fire was human caused, and was started within 1 km of the town.  Evacuees were able to return to their homes by May 30.

properties.name: Wildfire : Kelowna BC
properties.description: Kelowna  BC, August 28, 2005.  A 25-hectare forest fire was reported in Rose Valley near Kelowna BC.  Approximately 75 homes in the subdivision were evacuated and about 528 people registered with emergency social services after the evacuation order.  No injuries or casualties were reported.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northeast of Vancouver BC
properties.description: Northeast of Vancouver BC, July 1985.  During the same year, the Prairie provinces were struck with a severe drought (see 1985.002). During July, in northeast of Vancouver; a forest fire destroyed half a million acres of timberland.  One of the worst forest fires seasons on record.  Greater than 240,000 hectares of prime forest land burned.  More than 6,300 fire-fighters battling blazes.  The number of fires recorded in BC in 1985 were 3604.

properties.name: Wildfire : Valrita-Harty ON
properties.description: Valrita-Harty ON, 1987. 800 evacuated.

properties.name: Wildfire : Towns of Slave Lake, High Prairie, Little Buffalo, Lesser Slave Lake, Municipal Districts of Lesser Slave River, Red Earth Creek, and Loon Lake Whitefish Atikameg, and Woodland Cree First Nations AB
properties.description: Towns of Slave Lake, High Prairie, Little Buffalo, Lesser Slave Lake, Municipal Districts of Lesser Slave River, Red Earth Creek, and Loon Lake Whitefish Atikameg, and Woodland Cree First Nations AB, May 1, 2011 to May 21, 2011. 49 wildfires, beginning in the Slave Lake region of northern Alberta, spread prompting a forced evacuation. Penn West Petroleum, Exall Energy Corp., and Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. Halted drilling in the region, suspended production, and evacuated their employees. Canadian National (CN) Railway also halted their services in the region. As of May 16, 2011, more than 1,300 people had been evacuated from the area, and as wildfires continued to spread the number of evacuees rose to approximately 12,055 by May 19, 2011.

properties.name: Wildfire : Mishkeegogamang Ojibway First Nation (New Osnaburgh), Northern ON
properties.description: Mishkeegogamang Ojibway First Nation (New Osnaburgh), northern Ontario, June 22 to 27, 2011.  A state of emergency was declared as the First Nation community was overcome by smoke from more than 17 wildfires burning within 10 km of the community's housing area. The fire was estimated to be 37,000 hectares in size and not under control. 423 residents were evacuated between June 22 and June 24. Sioux Lookout, Greenstone (Gerldton) and Ignace declared States of Emergency as host communities. 10 MNR crews worked to bring fires under control while DND assisted with evacuations, and Health Canada assisted with medical services.

properties.name: Wildfire : Northern Ontario
properties.description: Northern Ontario, July 6 to 23, 2011. A series of  forest fires was sparked by a lightening storm on July 6, 2011. Fire personnel were not able to get the fires under control, and they quickly spread across Northern Ontario. 121 wildfires were reported as of July 20. Evacuation orders were put in place for communities in direct threat from fires as well as those communities suffering the combining impacts of smoke, power outages, food shortages and a lack of food storage capactity (many communities are only accessible by air). The following evacuations occurred: 535 people from Deer Lake First Nations (FN), 260 people from Cat Lake FN, 50 people from Mishkeegogamang FN, 280 people from Eabametoong FN (Fort Hope), 197 people from Keewaywin FN, approximately 1000 people from Kingfisher Lake FN, approximately 770 people from Sandy Lake FN, approximately 200 people from North Spirit Lake, and the entire communities of Keewaywin FN and Koocheching FN have been completely evacuated.   The wildfire has severly damaged more than 86 hydro poles and over 13 km of hydro lines, resulting in power outages across the northern region.

properties.name: Wildfire : Hall Lake SK
properties.description: Hall Lake SK, June 12 to 14, 2011. On June 12, 2011, the Saskatchewan Emergency Management Organization reported a 25 to 40 hectare wildfire burning approximately 3 to 4 kms from the La Ronge First Nation subcommunity of Hall Lake. 440 residents were evacuated. As of June 14, the wildfire was no longer considered to be a direct threat to residents, and the evacuation order was lifted.

properties.name: Wildfire : Red Lake ON
properties.description: Red Lake ON, June 1980. 43,664.76 ha of forest were destroyed by a fire, 5000 people had to be evacuated from the area, 3600 of which had to be airlifted to Winnipeg.

properties.name: Wildfire : British Columbia
properties.description: British Columbia, February 12, 1977. Total of 103,000 hectares burnt, 195,200 sheep and 3,365 cattle destroyed, 1,212,000 bales of hay burnt, 116 houses and 339 other buildings burnt.
